ygData.subject: Re: Question about Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, I think that speciation in novelty search should be examined on more domains than simple maze navigation. It may be a misleading place to test out

Subject: Re: Question about Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=fb64tx-BKx0ReDVBFxN4HFXwaSZTYjpS-9nEdtdJWGKzdIqSiaeEfNWtCQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: petar_chervenski

Hi Ken,

I think that speciation in novelty search should be examined on mo=
re 
domains than simple maze navigation. It may be a misleading place to 
t=
est out ideas, although this domain is easy to visualize and the 
results a=
re easier to interpret. For example consider 2 individuals 
separated by a =
wall, but their distance (the line through the wall) 
is so small that it i=
s considered a dense area. But getting around 
the wall requires another be=
havior than just hitting it from the 
other side. I guess that this issue b=
oils down to conflation, which 
we discussed already. 

By the way I made t=
hat experiment that you mentioned about, with the 
behavior characterizatio=
n being almost complete (in fact I use the 
last N points visited and sampl=
ed on regular intervals, i.e. not at 
each timestep) and performance was ac=
tually the same. Maybe even 
better. In fact the performance was the same (=
I mean number of 
evaluations to find a solution, not computation time) eve=
n when I 
give 1000 timesteps to individuals, so it is 2000D space (x and y=
 are 
2 dimentions not one). How did you compare distances in such a high 
=
dimentional space? I used just the average distance between points 
and it =
worked well. 

I think that novelty search then should be applicable to pro=
blems of 
any dimentionality. For example consider my biped project. A beha=
vior 
can be characterized simply by the joint angles over timesteps. In 
f=
act I am going to test NS combined with indirect encoding 
(HyperNEAT) on t=
his project soon. 
It is good to note that I made an experiment where I cha=
racterized 
the behavior as the network's outputs over time. That experimen=
t 
failed, as I guessed. So the behavior should be characterized not on 
ho=
w the network performs, but on how the *object* controlled by the 
network =
performs in its environment. So I think that it would be hard 
to apply nov=
elty search on domains where the actual network's outputs 
are used directl=
y as behavior, i.e. time series prediction for 
example. Because there are =
so many possibilities. But on the biped 
experiment, there are many constra=
ints, like gravity, inertia, 
collisions, etc. So it may be more effective =
there. 

OK well I agree about speciation, its main purpose is to protect n=
ew 
innovations, no matter how fitness is assigned, based either on 
novelt=
y or an objective function. I tried making the compatibility 
treshold so h=
igh that it means no speciation, and interestingly I 
didn't see any differ=
ence in the behavior density distribution. Maybe 
this kind of explains why=
 the solutions found by NS are so compact. 
In fact in most solutions the m=
aze is solved by a network without 
hidden nodes. But all tests and experim=
ents I make is on the maze 
domain, so the results may lie to me. I need to=
 test that on more 
domains to see if there is any difference, in order to =
have any 
strong conclusions. 

Peter 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenne=
th Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Are these issues regarding speciation=
 in novelty search really any
> different from the very same issues in fitn=
ess-based search?  I am
> still thinking about this issue, but I am not sur=
e they are really
> different.
> 
> In NEAT-based novelty search, speciatio=
n is still happening as 
normal.
>  One thing speciation does in fitness-ba=
sed search is protect unique
> individuals who may have lower fitness based=
 on the idea that they 
may
> take a while to reach their potential.  By an=
alogy, in novelty 
search,
> the effect is to protect genetically unique in=
dividuals who may not 
be
> very novel behaviorally on the chance that they=
 too may need some 
time
> to discover how to do something novel.
> 
> In o=
ther words, speciation means less greedy search.  In some cases,
> of cours=
e, being less greedy means being slower (such as when there 
is
> a single =
global optimum on a giant hill across the entire search
> space).  In parti=
cular, if the most fit (or most novel) individuals
> for whatever reason tu=
rn out to be the best jumping-off points for
> even more fit (or more novel=
) individuals, then the time spent on
> protected individuals was "wasted."=
  Yet that would not be the case 
in
> all domains, so to forego such prote=
ction is to take a risk in 
general.
> 
> It could be that in the maze doma=
in a greedier kind of novelty 
search
> would be faster.  But would that be=
 true in other domains?  An
> interesting question is the extent to which n=
ovelty search is better
> served by greediness than fitness-based search.  =
I am not sure if
> there is any basis to believe that it is.
> 
> The idea =
of taking species age into account might be interesting, 
but
> the questio=
n is still why this consideration would matter more or 
less
> than in fitn=
ess-based NEAT?
> 
> Overall, the way I see speciation interacting with nov=
elty search is
> to protect small species that have unique genotypes even i=
f those do
> not translate to novel behaviors in the hope that unique genot=
ypes 
may
> have the potential to turn into unique behaviors if given the 
=
chance. 
> 
> It is possible that I am misinterpreting the idea that you gu=
ys are
> developing, so please do clarify my comments if that is the case. =

> Novelty search does challenge a lot of common assumptions about 
search.=

> 
> ken
>

like..

If a

irst one maintains its high score). What we want is to

scores,

> > > > scores over a variety of maps perhaps it is =
